prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose observations of 37 class 0 and I sources (One example shown in Fig. 3) at 356 GHz in the extended configurations. We selected a complete sample of 37 Class 0/I sources in Lupus at a distance of 150 - 200 pc. All these sources have strong continuum emission either at 1.1 or 0.8 mm. We will simultaneously observe with four basebands: in addition to the continuum in the USB, We will simultaneously cover HCO+(J=4-3, 357 GHz) in USB, and H13CO+(J=4-3, 347 GHz) and CO(J=3-2, 345 GHz) in LSB. 2.2 minute integration will give us spatial resolution of 0".15 in the map and visibility domain (e.g. typical young binary separation in Harris et al. 2012, ApJ, 751, 115) and the 1 σ noise level of about 0.3 mJy beam−1. This is sufficient signal to noise ratio for visibility fitting if you consider the emission > 20 mJy from compact sources such as circumstellar disks (Chen et al. 2013, ApJ, 768, I10). We set 15 mJy at the lowest case. While still fitting within the observing parameters determined to be sufficient for the continuum observations, the spectral line detections that we obtain simultaneously with the continuum will put strong limits on the infall and outflow characteristics of the sources, particularly in relation to their continuum detections.

We propose observations of 37 class 0 and I sources (One example shown in Fig. 3) at 356 GHz in the extended configurations. We selected a complete sample of 37 Class 0/I sources in Lupus at a distance of 150 - 200 pc. All these sources have strong continuum emission either at 1.1 or 0.8 mm. We will simultaneously observe with four basebands: in addition to the continuum in the USB, We will simultaneously cover HCO+(J=4-3, 357 GHz) in USB, and H13CO+(J=4-3, 347 GHz) and CO(J=3-2, 345 GHz) in LSB. 2.2 minute integration will give us spatial resolution of 0".15 in the map and visibility domain (e.g. typical young binary separation in Harris et al. 2012, ApJ, 751, 115) and the 1 σ noise level of about 0.3 mJy beam−1. While still fitting within the observing parameters determined to be sufficient for the continuum observations, the spectral line detections that we obtain simultaneously with the continuum will put strong limits on the infall and outflow characteristics of the sources, particularly in relation to their continuum detections.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to carry out continuum imaging of Class 0 and I protostars in Lupus at band 7 with the ALMA. The main purpose of continuum imaging is a proto-binary survey: to determine the frequency, separation, and flux ratio (disk mass ratio) of binaries at the protostellar stage. ALMA’s high resolution comparable to typical separation of known proto-binaries (0”.15) and high sensitivity at submillimeter allow us to conduct a first complete survey of low-mass proto-binaries in Lupus. The band 7 continuum maps or visibility fit can reveal the configuration on tens of AU scale. HCO+(4-3) and CO(3-2) data will show how infalling envelope and outflow characteristics vary with evolution. The ALMA result will be an ultimate test of any theory to form a binary protostar and will identify unique sources to be followed up in the future.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
